key_title: Key to the species of Juncus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Juncaceae

source.author: Albrecht, D.E.
source.title: Juncus
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Albrecht, D.E. (1994). Juncus. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Pair of hyaline prophylls absent from the base of each flower, though an inflorescence bract may occasionally obscure the base of the flower
Base of individual flowers partially covered by a pair of hyaline prophylls inserted immediately below the flower (inflorescence bracts usually also present, e.g. at the base of the pedicels)
Culms with one or more blade-bearing sheaths
Culms with leaves reduced to basal cataphylls
Pith of culms at least in part interrupted by distinct small or large gaps (very rarely continuous throughout in J. brevibracteus, J. australis and J. subsecundus)
Pith of culms continuous throughout (very rarely interrupted by a few gaps in J. alexandri and J. pauciflorus)
Tepals with a deep red-brown longitudinal band on either side of the stramineous midrib or deep red-brown throughout; flowers strictly aggregated in subglobular clusters; pith loose and cobweb-like
Tepals without deep red-brown longitudinal bands or if bands present then usually faint and not combining the additional characters
Culms less than 1.2 mm diam., with fewer than 25 striations
Culms more than 1.5 mm diam., with more than 25 striations
Pigment bands on tepals intense; stamens 3; anthers 0.3–0.6 mm long; inner walls of open capsules without minute reddish flecks
Pigment bands on tepals comparatively faint; stamens 6 (rarely 3); anthers 0.6–1.0 mm long; inner walls of open capsules with minute reddish flecks
Upper part of culm and primary bract minutely scabrous; inflorescence branches and tepals usually also minutely scabrous
Upper part of culm, primary bract, inflorescence branches and tepals not scabrous
Cataphylls stramineous to pale brown towards the base
Cataphylls dark brown, reddish-brown or reddish-purple towards the base
Tepals 1.6–2.5 mm long; stamens usually 3 (rarely 4–6)
Tepals 2.6–3.8 mm long; stamens usually 6 (rarely 3)
Culms with very dense, distinctly white pith, not easily compressed; montane areas throughout eastern Victoria
Culms with loose cobweb-like whitish pith, usually easily compressed; lowland and foothill areas east of Rosedale
Mature capsules 2.8–3.5 mm long, longer than or equal to the tepals, the inner walls without minute reddish flecks; flowers not aggregated in subglobular clusters
Mature capsules 2.0–3.0 mm long, shorter than or equal to the tepals, the inner walls with minute reddish flecks; flowers aggregated in subglobular clusters
Stamens 6; capsules 2.2–3.5 mm long
Stamens usually 3, rarely 4 or 5 (rarely to 6 in J. continuus); capsules 1.5–2.7 mm long
Culms usually dull green to bluish-green, 2.5–8 mm diam., with 50–100 striations; flowers not widely spaced, inflorescence branches erect
Culms bright green, 0.4–2.2 mm diam., with 20–50 striations; flowers widely spaced on lax inflorescence branches
Immature culms glaucous; mature culms blue-green, 3–8.5 mm diam. with 70–120 striations; longest cataphyll 20–40 cm long; robust plant of lowland sites mostly north of the Great Dividing Range
Immature culms not glaucous; mature culms light to dark green, 1–4 mm diam. with 30–80 striations; longest cataphyll less than 25 cm long; on and south of the Great Dividing Range
Culms with very dense, distinctly white pith, not easily compressed
Culms with loose cobweb-like whitish pith, usually easily compressed
Tepals stramineous; capsules shorter than, or (in forms with inflorescences reduced to a single globular cluster) occasionally exceeding the tepals; cataphylls reddish-brown towards the base
Tepals brown throughout or with brown longitudinal bands on either side of a paler midrib; capsules clearly exceeding the tepals; cataphylls brown towards the base

Capsules 1.8–2.2 (rarely to 2.4) mm long, golden-brown in the upper half; tepals 1.5–2.4 (rarely to 2.6) mm long; stem striations moderately strongly raised; common in montane to subalpine areas of eastern Victoria
Capsules 2.2–2.6 mm long, brown in the upper half; tepals 1.9–3.0 mm long; stem striations not strongly raised; rare, restricted to the Otways
Male and female flowers on separate plants
Flowers bisexual
Culms 4–10 mm diam., (1.5–) 2–5 m high; stomates superficial
Culms 1.5–4 mm diam., not exceeding 2 m high; stomates sunken in pits

Culms robust, most more than 3 mm diam.; striations more than 70, crowded and not strongly raised; cataphylls dark brown, dark reddish-brown, dark reddish-orange or dark purplish-brown towards the base; inflorescence branches not flexuose
Culms less than 3 mm diam., or if broader then striations fewer than 70, cataphylls pale to medium brown towards the base, and/or inflorescence branches flexuose

Tepals (2.7–) 3–3.5 mm long; culm striations very crowded and often difficult to distinguish from adjacent tissue when culm is examined just above the apex of the longest cataphylls; stomates sunken in pits
Tepals 1.5–3 mm long; culm striations easily distinguished from adjacent tissue; stomates superficial (or slightly sunken in J.. semisolidus)
Mature culms bluish-green, immature culms glaucous; pith interrupted for a short distance below inflorescence, continuous below; lowland species occurring mostly north of the Great Dividing Range
Mature and immature culms green; pith interrupted throughout or interrupted in the lower part and continuous above

Tepals 1.5–2.3 mm long; secondary bract subulate, usually less than 10 mm long; pith of culms typically with small gaps, often interrupted in the lower part and continuous above; culms not easily split when compressed; cataphylls usually tightly enveloping culm, to c. 25 cm long; rare montane and subalpine species of eastern Victoria

Tepals 2–3 mm long; secondary bract acuminate, more than 10 mm long; pith of culms typically with large gaps; culms readily splitting longitudinally when compressed near the midpoint; cataphylls loose, to c. 40 cm long; lowland and foothill areas in southern Victoria, rarely montane

Flowers scattered along the inflorescence branchlets (rarely somewhat clustered in J. sarophorus), the density of the inflorescence varying from open (when few branchlets are present) to dense (when numerous branchlets are present)
Flowers clustered on the inflorescence branchlets (rarely somewhat scattered in J.gregiflorus), inflorescences composed of one to many clusters
Tepals 2.5 mm or less long
Tepals more than 2.5 mm long
Cataphylls pale to medium brown towards the base
Cataphylls dark brown to dark reddish-brown towards the base
Culms 0.5–2 (–2.3) mm diam., with less than 40 moderately strongly to strongly raised striations
Culms 1–6 mm diam., with more than 40 weakly raised striations
Tepals 2–4 mm long; capsules 2–3.5 mm long
Tepals 1.3–2 mm long; capsules 1.5–2 mm long
Culms dull green to greyish-green or glaucous; at least some inflorescence branches curving downwards; north of the Great Dividing Range
Culms bright light green; inflorescence branches erect; eastern Victoria, south of the Great Dividing Range
Capsules slightly shorter than or equal to the tepals; culm striations strongly raised and comparatively widely spaced; stomates sunken in pits
Capsules clearly longer than the tepals; culm striations moderately strongly raised and comparatively crowded; stomates superficial
Culms readily splitting longitudinally when compressed; pith very open, consisting mainly of air spaces; capsules 2–2.5 mm long; culm striations 30–80
Culms not easily split longitudinally when compressed; pith with air spaces and partitions often ± equal; capsules 1.5–2 mm long; culm striations 25–40 (rarely to 45)
Culm striations fewer than 35, very rarely to 40, strongly raised, coarse and easily counted
Culm striations more than 40 or if fewer (as very rarely the case in J .remotiflorus) then striations fine and not strongly raised
Cataphylls dark shiny brown to almost black towards the base; capsules dark brown; culm striations 10–20
Cataphylls pale or occasionally medium brown towards the base; capsules stramineous to golden-brown; culm striations 20–35 (rarely to 40)

Culm striations very crowded and often difficult to distinguish from adjacent tissue when culm is examined just above the apex of the longest cataphylls; cataphylls usually reddish-brown to dark brown towards the base; stomates sunken in pits; widespread species
Culm striations fine but easily distinguished from adjacent tissue; cataphylls usually pale to medium brown towards the base; stomates superficial; low-rainfall areas only
At least some inflorescence branches curving downwards; longest cataphyll more than 13 cm long; tepals 2–2.8 mm long; usually in sites with permanent or semi-permanent water
Inflorescence branches always erect; longest cataphyll less than 13 cm long; tepals 2.5–4 mm long; usually in watercourses and depessions that are dry for much of the year
Tepals with conspicuous brown to red-brown longitudinal bands on either side of the stramineous midrib or deep brown to red-brown throughout; pith loose and cobweb-like, usually scarcely interrupted
Tepals stramineous or with very faint brown to red-brown longitudinal bands; pith various
Culms 0.5–1 (–1.2) mm diam., with fewer than 25 striations
Culms 1–4 mm diam., with more than 25 striations

Tepals 1.6–2.5 mm long, with brown, not particularly intense pigment bands; inflorescence consisting of few to many loose flower clusters; capsules with a golden-brown apex; culm striations not prominent; occurring at low to moderate altitudes

Tepals 2–3 mm long, with intense red-brown pigment bands; inflorescence usually constisting of few, dense subglobular flower clusters; capsules with a dark red-brown or occasionally golden-brown apex; culm striations fairly prominent; occurring at moderate to high altitudes
Cataphylls pale to medium brown towards the base; stomates superficial
Cataphylls dark brown to dark red-brown towards the base, or if paler (as rarely the case in J. flavidus and J. australis) then stomates sunken in pits

Culms bright light green with 40–80 weakly raised striations; tepals brown (later turning stramineous) 1.6–2.5 mm long; longest cataphyll to 22 cm long; eastern Victoria, south of the Great Dividing Range

Culms dull green to greyish- or bluish-green with fewer than 40 strongly raised striations; tepals stramineous or rarely faintly reddish-tinged, 2–4 mm long; longest cataphyll to 12 cm long; widespread species
Culms bright green; capsules usually with a somewhat flattened top; tepals acute, 1.6–2.4 (rarely to 2.7) mm long; stomates superficial
Culms dull green to greyish- or bluish-green; capsules usually with an obtuse to subacute top; tepals acute to acuminate, 1.5–3.5 mm long; stomates superficial or sunken in pits

Culms readily splitting longitudinally when compressed; capsules equal to or exceeding tepals, with a reddish-brown apex; culm striations fine, moderately strongly raised and fairly crowded; stomates superficial

Culms less easily split longitudinally when compressed; capsules equal to or shorter than sepals, with a golden-brown apex; culm striations either coarser and less crowded or very crowded and often difficult to distinguish from adjacent tissue; stomates sunken in pits
Tepals 2.2–3 mm long; anthers 0.5–0.8 mm long; culm striations 30–60, moderately strongly raised and at a regular distance apart; cataphylls dark brown towards the base

Tepals (2.7–) 3–3.5 mm long; anthers 0.7–1.2 mm long; culm striations 50–130, not strongly raised, very crowded and often difficult to distinguish from adjacent tissue when culm is examined just above the apex of the longest cataphylls; cataphylls usually reddish-brown to dark brown towards the base
Tufted non-rhizomatous annual; sheath margins of lower lamina-bearing leaves merging gradually or abruptly into blade margins, without auricles
Tufted or rhizomatous perennials, sheath margins of lower lamina-bearing leaves produced at apex on either side into small auricles that ± meet in the middle of the leaf

At least some inflorescences usually with two or more bracts more than 5 cm long; auricles of uppermost leaves exceeding the sinus by 0.5–6 mm; leaf tips truncate and ± irregularly toothed, rarely acute

At most only one inflorescence bract more than 5 cm long; auricles of uppermost leaves exceeding the sinus by less than 1 mm; leaf tips acute or obtuse, rarely eroding and appearing toothed; anthers more than 0.6 mm long, or if shorter (as in J. capillaceus) then the leaves filiform and tepals not exceeding 3 mm long
Tepals less than 4 mm long, mature capsules less than 3.5 mm long
Tepals 4 mm or more long or if less than 4 mm (as rarely the case in J. imbricatus) then mature capsules more than 3.5 mm long
Plants forming open swards, with long rhizomes; anthers 1–2.2 mm long; tepals with intense reddish-brown margins; 1–2 culm leaves present in addition to the basal leaves
Plants densely tufted with short rhizomes; anthers 0.3–0.8 mm long; tepals with pale margins or pale reddish; leaves strictly basal or sub-basal
Base of plant with more or less persistent fibrous remains of leaf sheaths; culms 0.2–0.5 mm diam; anthers 0.3–0.4 mm long
Base of plant lacking persistent fibrous remains of leaf sheaths; culms 0.7–1.5 mm diam; anthers 0.4–0.6 mm long

Inflorescence usually consisting of 1–several ± stellate clusters of flowers; when multiple flower clusters present, one or more of the inflorescence branches arched or decurved; seed surface reticulation obvious at low (X 10) magnification
Inflorescence not consisting of distinct clusters of flowers, flowers spaced along the ascending inflorescence branches;; seed surface reticulation not obvious at low magnification
Plants forming open swards, with long rhizomes; anthers 1.1–2 mm long
Plants densely tufted with short rhizomes; anthers 0.3–0.6 mm long
Base of plant with more or less persistent fibrous remains of leaf sheaths; capsule much longer than tepals (by 1–2 mm); capsules 3.5–6.5 mm long; anthers 0.7–1.4 mm long
Base of plant lacking persistent fibrous remains of leaf sheaths; capsule about as long as tepals; capsules (2.5–)2.8–3.5(–4.5) mm long; anthers 0.4–0.6 mm long

Leaf-blades solid, without internal septa; leaf-sheath margins merging into blade margins (rarely with a lobe on each side) or meeting in the middle of the leaf (but not produced beyond this point into auricles)

Leaf-blades hollow and transversely septate (though the partitions sometimes difficult to see in fine-leaved species such as J.bulbosus); leaf-sheath margins produced at the apex into small auricles that meet towards the middle of the leaf in a sinus (or auricles absent in J. ensifolius)
Leaf-blades terete and pungent; inflorescence appearing lateral to an erect bract
Leaf-blades flat or channelled, not pungent; inflorescence appearing terminal
Mature capsules 4–6 mm long, about twice the length of the tepals, usually golden-brown coloured, slightly darker in the upper half; seeds 1.3–2 mm long, with conspicuous hyaline appendages

Mature capsules 2.5–3 mm long, slightly exceeding to slightly shorter than the tepals, usually dark reddish-brown to almost black (occasionally golden-brown); seeds 0.5–1 mm long, lacking appendages or with short inconspicuous appendages
Tufted non-rhizomatous annual; outer tepals twice as long as the capsule
Tufted or rhizomatous perennials (occasionally annual in J. planifolius); outer tepals slightly shorter to slightly longer than the capsule

Outer tepals (3.2–) 3.5–5.5 mm long, with a broad, minutely scabrous midrib; leaves grey-green, junction of blade and sheath often in an ± inconspicuous membranous lobe on one or both sides; plants with long, tough scaly rhizome
Outer tepals 1.5–3.5 (–4) mm long, with a smooth midrib; leaves green, junction of blade and sheath without lobes; plants with or without a rhizome

Dwarf alpine plant forming cushions or sparse mats with leaves to 3 cm long and 2 mm wide; inflorescences a solitary 1–5-flowered cluster on stems subequal to or exceeding the leaves by less than 2 cm

Tufted plants of lower altitudes with at least some leaves greater than 3 cm long or 2 mm wide; inflorescences usually consisting of more than one flower cluster, but if all reduced to a solitary cluster then at least some of the clusters with more than 5 flowers and/or on stems exceeding the leaves by more than 2 cm

Stamens 6; leaf-blades to 2.5 mm wide (when flattened), channelled (except for the tip); tepals 2.2–3.2 mm long; anthers subequal in length to filaments; primary inflorescence bract usually exceeding the flower cluster(s)

Stamens 3, very rarely 4–6; leaf-blades 1–11 mm wide, flat or channelled; tepals 1.5–2.5 mm long; anthers shorter than filaments; primary inflorescence bract usually shorter than the flower cluster(s)
Leaf-blades pluritubulose, with transverse septa extending across the width of the individual longitudinal tubes
Leaf-blades unitubulose with transverse septa extending across the whole width of the blade, and/or blades less than 1 mm wide and number of longitudinal tubes difficult to discern
Basal leaves with setaceous, usually bitubulose blades 0.3–0.6 mm wide; cauline leaves terete to slightly compressed, ± unitubulose, less than 1.5 mm wide
Leaf-blades strongly laterally compressed, 1.2–5.5 mm wide, with several longitudinal tubes
Leaf sheath margin without auricles; capsules 2.5–3.2 mm long, subequal to or slightly exceeding the tepals, with a subacute, shortly mucronate apex
Leaf sheath margin with distinct obtuse auricles; capsules 4–5 mm long, distinctly exceeding the tepals and tapering gradually to an acute-acuminate apex

Plants with a tuft of setaceous, inconspicuously bitubulose (microscopic examination often necessary) basal leaves 0.3–0.6 mm wide that are sometimes withered in old plants; plants ± bulbous at base, with or without very short rhizomes, often spreading vegetatively by layering of proliferous shoots that arise from nodes of the culm and from the inflorescence; capsules subequal to or slightly exceeding the tepals, with an obtuse shortly mucronate apex
Not combining the above characters
Stamens 3
Stamens 6
Capsules golden-brown to slightly reddish-brown; seeds 0.3–0.4 mm long; outer tepals 2.5–3.5 mm long; anthers shorter than or occasionally equal to filaments
Capsules dark red-brown at least in the upper half; seeds 0.4–0.6 mm long; outer tepals 3.1–4.5 mm long; anthers longer than or equal to filaments
Mature capsules dark brown, dark reddish-brown or almost black throughout or in the upper part; tepals usually strongly tinged red-brown
Mature capsules green, light brown or golden-brown throughout, without a strongly contrasting darker apex; tepals ± tinged red-brown (often only towards the apex)
Mature capsules equal to or distinctly exceeding the tepals, with an acute and mucronate or beaked apex; seeds 0.4–0.6 mm long
Mature capsules shorter than the outer tepals, with a broadly obtuse-truncate and mucronate apex; seeds 0.3–0.4 mm long
Capsule tapering rather abruptly to a beak 1–2 mm long; anthers 0.8–1.5 mm long
Capsule tapering gradually or rather abruptly to a distinct mucro not exceeding 0.8 mm long; anthers 0.5–0.9 mm long
Tepals 2–3 mm long; fruit clusters usually less than 8 mm diam
Tepals 3.1–4.5 mm long; fruit clusters mostly 8–10 mm diam

Inflorescence of many discrete clusters of flowers, each cluster clearly separated; inflorescence 5–20(–30) x 2–15 cm; flower-head peduncles 0.4 mm thick or thinner; tepals soft-textured, outer tepals longer than inner; capsule often obovate, subequal to inner tepals; seeds ellipsoid 0.4–0.5 mm long x c. 0.2 mm wide

Inflorescence of few to many clusters of flowers, at least some clusters not well separated; inflorescence 2–10 x 2–4 cm; flower-head peduncles 0.45 mm thick or thicker; tepals rigid, outer and inner subequal; capsule ± ovoid, shorter than tepals; seeds broadly ellipsoid 0.3–0.4 mm long x c. 0.2 mm wide

Leaves 0.3–1 (–1.5) mm wide, the transverse septa often inconspicuous; inflorescences with 1–5 flower clusters; culms to 14 cm long but often much shorter; higher altitudes or intermediate altitudes in cold-air basins
Leaves 0.5–4 mm wide, when less than 1 mm wide transverse septa conspicuous; inflorescences with up to 75 flower clusters; culms usually more than 14 cm long; various altitudes

Mature capsules (2.5–) 3–4.6 mm long, exceeding tepals by 1–2 mm, tapering gradually or slightly contracted below the acute-acuminate apex; tepals 1.8–3 mm long; flower clusters composed of up to 10 flowers
Mature capsules 2.3–2.5 mm long, exceeding tepals by less than 0.8 mm, contracted rather abruptly to an acuminate apex; tepals 1.8–2.3 mm long; flower clusters composed of up to 3 flowers
Rhizome long-creeping, stout (c. 2-5 mm diam.); outer tepals shorter than inner; tepals with long-acuminate apices reflexed at maturity

Rhizome absent,  or short and slender (< 2 mm diam.), plants usually tufted (or at times with stems submerged or buried in sand and rooting at proximal nodes in Juncus articulatus); tepals of  ±  equal length or outer ones longer; tepals with acute to obtuse or acuminate apices erect or only slightly reflexed
Capsule tapering rather abruptly to a beak 1–2 mm long; anthers 0.8–1.5 mm long
Capsule tapering gradually or rather abruptly to a distinct mucro not exceeding 0.8 mm long; anthers 0.5–1 mm long

Outer tepals 2–3 mm long; inner tepals ovate, obtuse to acute, equal to or shorter than the outer tepals; anthers equal to or longer than the filaments; fruiting clusters 5–9 mm wide; plants commonly forming swards or sometimes tufted

Outer tepals 3–4.5 mm long (rarely to 2.5 mm); inner tepals narrowly ovate, acute-acuminate, equal to or longer than the outer tepals; anthers shorter than the filaments; fruiting clusters 6–14 mm wide; plants tufted
Capsule exceeding the tepals by 1 mm or more at maturity, 3.5–6.7 mm long, gradually tapered to an acute apex
Capsule not exceeding the tepals or exceeding the tepals by less than 1 mm at maturity, 3–4.5 mm long, contracted rather abruptly or rarely tapered gradually to an acute apex
